title: At close of business on 15 December 2021, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 3 November 2021?
preds: As the central bank prepares to remove emergency stimulus measures to support the economy, sustained inflation could force the Fed to move faster than it would like, before the labor market is fully healed. In newly released minutes from their latest policymaking meeting, Fed officials appear split, with “various” members arguing that interest rates should stay near zero for a couple of yearst, while “a number” said that rates would need to go up next year, with inflation most “likely to remain elevated in 2022 with risks to the upside.” A recent Fed survey suggests that consumer expectations for inflation are running at historic high. Dealbook NYT newsletter by Ross Sorkin

Liftoff will not begin until the end of Taper. Taper will end middle of 2022. Fed funds rate will stay the same until the middle of 2022.
Federal Funds Target Range - Upper Limit chart can be seen at https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DFEDTARU

This past week, Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell acknowledged that supply bottlenecks have been longer-lasting than originally anticipated, and he expects inflation pressures to remain high in coming months before easing.  
However, he also noted that “…they will abate, and as they do, inflation is expected to drop back toward our longer-run 2% goal.” This supports our core assessment of no change in the target funds rate by the December FOMC meeting.  
However, the disclosure that “as reopening continues, bottlenecks, hiring difficulties, and other constraints could again prove to be greater and more enduring than anticipated, posing upside risks to inflation” serves to validate our asymmetrical risk view that assigns a higher probability to a rate hike than to a rate cut.  
We therefore make no changes to our conditional probability ratings: Probability of a decrease in the funds rate: 1%
Probability of no change in the funds rate: 94%
Probability of an increase in the funds rate: 5%
Powell's testimony significantly lowers the probability for both a rate cut and a rate increase by the December FOMC meeting.

Just to explain my logic.  I don't see any situation in which the rate is lower.  While higher is a possibility, I think market unease as a result of a potential default along with potential tapering will keep rates unchanged.

The Fed is in the process of gradually "normalizing" monetary policy as economic activity improves.  But this will occur in a sequential manner, with the Fed first "tapering" its purchases of treasury and mortgage-backed securities (currently $120 billion per month - $80 billion in treasuries and $40 billion in mortgage-backed securities) before it begins to raise the Fed funds rate.  This assumes then that the Fed will first have to signal its intent to taper before it begins to signal its intent to raise rates.  With a tapering announcement likely at some point in the fourth quarter (likely at the November or December FOMC meeting), the probability of an announced increase in the target  funds rate prior to the December FOMC meeting is exceedingly low.   An announced increase in the target funds rate by the December FOMC meeting would only likely occur if the economy continues to overshoot the Fed's estimates and inflation significantly exceeds the Fed target rate (2% PCE deflator).   An announced lowering of the target funds rate would only occur if there were a sudden exogenous shock (e.g., large scale terror attack; vaccine resistant variant of the COVID-19; financial crisis; geopolitical conflict) that caused a massive economic/financial market dislocation. I would estimate that the probability that the Fed raises the target range for the funds rate would be about five times more likely than the Fed reducing its target range for the funds rate (which would imply negative rates).

"Lower" has some chance, but "Higher" would require a major catastrophe to become a reality before 2023.
I'd call it 0.01% "Lower..."
The Fed has boxed itself into a corner by predicting a rapid decline in inflation in 2022 Opinion by Peter Coy

There are two (or three) FOMC meetings before the close of this question; https://bit.ly/2W8IEaO. In the July 28, 2021 minutes the FED stated; "The Committee decided to keep the target range for the federal funds rate at 0 to 1/4 percent and expects it will be appropriate to maintain this target range until labor market conditions have reached levels consistent with the Committee's assessments of maximum employment and inflation has risen to 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time." (https://bit.ly/37VH92m) While there has been an improvement in the overall tome of the US economy, the July 2021 Dept Labour Statistics indicate that employment levels are still well down on pre-pandemic levels; "The unemployment rate declined by 0.5 percentage point to 5.4 percent in July, and the number of unemployed persons fell by 782,000 to 8.7 million. These measures are down considerably from their highs at the end of the February-April 2020 recession. However, they remain well above their levels prior to the coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic (3.5 percent and 5.7 million, respectively, in February 2020). (See table A-1. See the box note
at the end of this news release for more information about how the household survey and its measures were affected by the coronavirus pandemic.)" (https://bit.ly/3j04WVc) . Thus, in spite of lots of 'talk' of tapering, IMO there's little probability of an increase in the FED target rate. Even if the FED should, as forward guidance, advise that tapering will begin in Q4/21 or Q1/22, that is still, relatively speaking, very accommodative and unlikely to affect the reserve target rate within the time frames of this question. Additionally, the apparent slowdown in China and the fear of growing Delta variant Covid cases is likely to keep a cap on economic activity in the next 3-5 months. So, I am now falling in line with the crowd.  @Wildwood2000 / @Juliabizz / @MCowley / @SE_Meyer ? @bobrown

https://www.cnbc.com/2021/07/28/fed-decision-july-2021.html With the Fed likely on hold relative to interest rates at least until late-2022, investors have been looking for clues as to when the monthly bond purchases might start to be pulled back. However, officials insist the current surge is temporary and will abate once supply chain bottlenecks ease, demand returns to normal levels, and certain items, particularly used car prices, also get back to baseline. Heading into this week’s meeting, markets were pricing in zero chance of any rate increases this year. However, the likelihood of a 2022 hike rose from 54.4% before the meeting to 62% afterward, with futures fully pricing in the first hike by March 2023, according to CME’s FedWatch tool and Reuters.
inflationary pressure will force a move
If inflation doesn’t settle down there may be some pressure to raise rates
No point in going lower. Inflation, plus, so much cash already circulating...
